healing, a change of heart, or another spiritual concern of my heart he 
will answer. Why is there murder, rape, and other horric deeds going on is 
because of us. We have free will, an example: if Chris went crazy and 
killed a man it was because he used his free will to do so. Free will is 
the reason why this world is as corrupted as it is. Because ppl abuse it. 
Ppl's decisions to either do right or wrong. If I got killed it's not God's 
fault, it would be the person who killed me. ﻿

to just stay out of it this time, but I have just one question for you: Why

do not believe he exists, but I find it flattering if someone wishes

wish God's blessings on you. Perhaps you have something held against my God

I'm sorry that you do not understand

comments.text:
+Landon Hight My JK Rowling reference was to suggest that a great fiction 
writer of the day could have written them. Lets face it Landon, there is a 
lot of magic and mystery in the gospels.
The Synoptic Gospels are anonymously written. Its not my fault. But they 
are. 
I see exactly why the gospel of Thomas was thrown out. Its 150 years after 
the events. Its hearsay of the greatest kind. Just as Mathew and Mark are. 
 Just as there no way of knowing who wrote Luke - it was anonymously 
written 80-100 years "after" the alleged events. .
comments.author: ozskipper

comments.text:
+Rahab2011 Yes, its condescending. You know I dont believe in your deity. 
Why would you say something so condescending?
Yes, prayer is like meditation.  My reference is play on words. One could 
pray for the life of a sick child, therefore do nothing, or one could take 
the child to the doctor.   Hence the mordant humor.
comments.author: ozskipper

comments.text:
I'm just going to jump back in for a moment, and just say that +ozskipper is 
stretching just a bit. For some reason I do not quite believe that JK 
Rowling could have written the gospels. Actually, the fact that these books 
were so easily agreed upon in the early days of the church facilitates the 
idea that they were, in fact, written by the original apostles. Jesus sent 
the apostles out to spread the word of his good news. Through this, they 
reached many places, and were able to tell their stories to many people. It 
is true that the gospels were written several years after Jesus left earth, 
but that shouldn't come as a surprise. Oral tradition was highly valued 
back in those days, and people would not take changing an apostle's words 
lightly. Actually, them eventually writing it down should be almost 
shocking. It would not be a strange assumption to think that the only 
reason they decided to write down some of what Jesus did in his life was 
because the Holy Spirit guided them to do so. 

A gospel labeled "The Gospel of Thomas" (I'm sure as someone who studied 
the Bible, you know who Thomas is. He was an apostle that we regularly 
address as 'Doubting Thomas') That gospel was thrown out of the running for 
canon because it was written around AD 150. My point with all of this is 
that 
1. At the very least, the gospels were written within the lifetimes of the 
respective apostles
2. The gospels were actually most likely written by Matthew, Mark, Luke, 
and John because the people who had heard their stories (and that would be 
quite a few) would have a problem going along with what they knew to be a 
lie
comments.author: Landon Hight

comments.text:
+ozskipper I will stipulate that to ask God to bless you is insulting to

missing out on.  God bless you.

comments.text:
+ozskipper I use the word "could" because there is a possibility that there 
is other reasoning. I realize that I am not God, and therefore cannot say 
that this is without a doubt why he did something. I use the word could not 
because I doubt the Bible, but because I doubt myself.
How is this twisting words? Twisting words is when you sit in a high school 
English class, and the teacher says that the author wrote of a blue sky 
because he was sad when the author just decided a blue sky would be a nice 
touch there. This "twisting of words" is just like the bat thing. You are 
refusing to believe that the listeners of the original text may have had a 
different definition of cud or bird. This is a typical atheist/agnostic 
response. That is, assuming that I am wrong just because that is not what 
you think it means. I do agree that a lot of Christians choose to disregard 
parts of the Bible that they do not understand or agree with, but that does 
not mean that the Bible is wrong. 
Perhaps (yes, this is the same as could for the same reason stated above), 
God gave us minds to think for ourselves so that we could read his words, 
and get something different out of it each time we read it because it is 
not verbatim.
comments.author: Landon Hight

comments.text:
+Landon Hight I will repeat myself Landon. The word "could" installs doubt. 
Thats interesting. 
  Rabbits do not chew cud.  Cud is regurgitated from the reticulorumen of 
such animals. Suggesting otherwise is twisting the words again. 
Of course we cant expect what was written thousands of years ago to be 
true. It was written by scientifically uneducated people. If there was a 
deity involved in the writing of the book, he would have fixed those 
errors. Obviously, he didnt. 
So far, you have twisted the words in every thing I have presented to you. 
 Yet you dont twist the words of the gospels or parts of the bible you 
"want" to believe as verbatim.This is a typical "believer" response.  Even 
within christianity, some believe different parts of the bible, while other 
disregard those verses. It shows how mixed belief structures can be. If the 
bible were truly infallible, it would be written where everything was taken 
verbatim.
comments.author: ozskipper

comments.text:
+ozskipper I'm sorry, but how is it that people couldn't understand it? The 
point of figures of speech is to help people understand what is being said.

And here we go again, saying that it definitely was not used back in the 
day. This is why I use the word "could" so that no one can accuse me of 
being arrogant or anything like that. I use the word could to show that 
this "flaw" does not necessarily make it fallible.

Get ready because soon you will read an answer to the rabbit controversy.

Rabbits eat droppings that did not fully digest. This is the same as 
chewing cud except for the fact that animals that chew what we now consider 
cud have four stomachs. "This is not chewing cud" one may argue, and that 
is understandable. That is, until you consider what I clarified several 
times with the bats. We cannot expect something written thousands of years 
ago to adhere to the scientific differences of today (excluding things such 
as the world being round and stuff because that is a matter of scientific 
fact rather than the possibility of only a change of 
definition/characterization). That being said, chewing cud could have been 
eating food that had already been eaten.
comments.author: Landon Hight

comments.text:
+Landon Hight So if people couldnt understand it. Isnt that a flaw in its 
writing? Its a failure to communicate properly. If it needs to have its 
words twisted over and over, thats definitely a sign that it is poor 
communication.   Have you ever got out a highlighter pen and marked the 
literal vs the metaphoric?
Have you ever marked the things you dont believe?  Eg Jesus wanting parents 
to stone their children

Cmon, do you know the verse I am refereing to regarding all fours?.  Its 
written very simply.All winged insects that go on all fours are detestable 
to you"  Yet, you twist the words again. Getting down on all fours is a 
modern colloquialism. It certainly wasnt a bronze age one.

Get ready because soon we are going to talk about how the bible suggests 
that rabbits "chew the cud"
comments.author: ozskipper

top_comment.text:
What a load....   What do you need god for? Can't human beings provide 
love, joy, support and compassion without being "called upon"? If somebody 
chooses to do nothing to help another, they can simply say "well....god 
didn't call on me".....

It's garbage. We have a responsibility to each other and it has nothing to 
do with a god. It has to do with love and compassion which are innate human 
qualities. Turning away from somebody in need is deplorable whether "god" 
calls on you or not. Forget prayer; if you're praying for yourself, get off 
your knees and do something to help yourself; and if your praying for 
somebody else, get off your knees and do something to help them. Remember, 
the two minutes that you waste on prayer could be the difference between 
life and death for another.﻿
top_comment.author: Larry L

comments.text: That's good to know. :)
comments.author: Ryan LevRon Jr

comments.text:
+Ryan LevRon Jr
There`s no way that I could prove you right or wrong regarding a higher 
power. As I said, I have no issue with the possibility of one existing. On 
the other hand, I would argue that religion has impaired medical and 
scientific progress in ways that we could never imagine; from killing 
Galileo right up to blocking stem cell research.

To be clear, there`s a difference between `not believing` and `rejecting`. 
I don`t believe in a god only because I have never been presented with 
evidence of one; that doesn`t mean that I whole-heartedly reject the 
proposition.
comments.author: Larry L

comments.text:
As a Christian I am taught and believe that man wrote the Bible, however he 
was inspired by God to do so. The 12 Apostles that walked with Jesus, all 
of them took part in writing a section of the Bible, Paul, writing the 
most. With all due respect Larry, I am not insulting you nor am I calling 
anyone stupid, but in my opinion mankind would not be as advanced 
medically, scientifically or intelligently without God or a "higher power" 
as some do believe.

Like I stated, this is my opinion.
comments.author: Ryan LevRon Jr

comments.text:
+Ryan LevRon Jr
It`s truly refreshing to read such an honest reply; especially when so many 
christians attempt to make up answers in response to a question that simply 
cannot be answered.

In response to your other posts, I understand why people choose to believe 
in a deity. Frankly, if you find yourself praying for a new car I think 
it`s a good time to conduct a priority check. It`s my position that 
anything one might pray for can be achieved or acquired without 
supernatural intervention. It`s my "wish" that more people would come to 
accept the fact and take greater strides in achieving their own goals.

In regards to so-called "miracles"; well, this is a sore spot for me. I 
take tremendous exception to crediting god simply because modern medical 
science can't provide an answer. I get even angrier when doctors use the 
word miracle - it's akin to saying "I am the last step before god, if I 
don't understand it, then it must be supernatural"; it's arrogance to the 
extreme. Only 100 years ago medical science didn't understand influenza and 
millions of people died; today our understanding is far more advanced.

I also hope you understand that I, like most atheists, do not take issue 
with "A" god, we take issue with any human interpretation of god. Priests, 
Rabbi's, Preachers and Shaman are all humans; the bible itself was written 
by human's - everything you have learned about "god" has been the result of 
somebody else's interpretation. The reality is, religion and god are not 
synonymous; religion uses god to further an often evil agenda.

Fear begets violence, religion thrives on fear; FEAR RELIGION!!!
comments.author: Larry L

comments.text:
+Larry L You bring up a lot of points "why would I care so much about other 
human beings? The truth is, I can't provide an intelligent or quantifiable 
answer to that "

That goes hand in hand with the question " Why does God allow suffering in 
this world ? "

The truth is, I no one provide an intelligent or quantifiable answer to

comments.author: Ryan LevRon Jr

comments.text:
+Ryan LevRon Jr God does his best work in hopeless situations because he 
wants us to get so low, and get to a place where we believe there is no 
hope and we want to end it all that we call on his name and he will be 
there, because, think about it, why do you need him when everything is 
going good? That is why he answers in the storm ( of our lives ). One more 
thing I will end you with, the bible says that "God makes everything 
beautiful in his timing" So, Christians and people who are hungry to know 
about God, be patience, the answer won't come when you want it or think you 
need it, it will come right on time when God knows you absolutely need the 
answer. That is why Faith and Patience are one of the hardest things to 
have in this world, people do not like to wait, I am included.
comments.author: Ryan LevRon Jr

comments.text:
+Larry L Since you are being respectful, if you do not mind let me share my 
experiences. First I will copy and paste some of what you said and give you 
my experiences from them. 

Let me respectfully say this, I admire that you do all of those things 
which we believe as Christians are holy, and I respect that you are not 
rude nor are insulting anyone on here, so I will make my claim respectfully 
due to my experiences, like you have.

"there are things in life that are outside of our control - bad things 
happen to good people but how we process those events is within our 
control. "

To answer this, the bible says, "it rains on the just and the unjust" which 
interprets that bad things happen to good people, and bad people, it 
doesn't matter if you're going to heaven or not, life happens.

I've had a lot of bad situations in life ( as I am sure you have ) and a 
lot of good situations. With that being said let me quote this line and 
give you my experiences and thoughts. 

"So why give god credit when things go well while never holding him/her/it 
accountable when they go poorly? For that matter, why involve a god at all?"

In my everyday life I have been in situations such as: Not getting the 
vehicle that I wanted, or the house I wanted, maybe some clothes I would've 
liked to have ( all of these I have prayed for ). With that being said, 
because I did not get those things I think to myself, "maybe God did not 
want me to have the vehicle, house or clothes at that time because he knew 
if I would've purchased them then I would've had financial trouble later 
on, maybe it was not my time to receive such rewards" Now, you're reading 
this and wondering, how is this so bad? Well, entirely it is not, but to 
some people it is. As far as the starving child, the people dieing of 
cancer, ect. Unlike some other religious leaders who wrote off pain and 
suffering as just being illusions, Jesus was honest. He told us the truth. 
He said in John 16:33, “You will have suffering in this world.” He didn’t 
say you might – he said it is going to happen.  

Therefore, we might best respond by saying that God does not Will "bad" 
things to happen in life. Rather, "bad" things happen in the freedom that 
comes with the gift of life. When "bad" things happen to any of God's 
children, God is grieved and suffers with us, experienced most vividly in 
the hurt and suffering of Jesus the Christ for all humanity. Any "bad" 
thing which happens is never the last word. Rather, God is the deepest and 
last word, and that word is love and eternal life with God.

By this God have man choice, weather to go to heaven or hell and it is by 
mans choice that there is so much bad in this world, he gave us wisdom to 
invent things and create bad that way we have choice. Let me answer this 
with a story about Noah, God allowed the Earth to flood to get rid of all 
the sin in the world. The bible talks about when Cain killed Able that Cain 
was cursed for 4 generations and thus his family with him, that means for 
40 years his children and grand children were cursed due to actions of 
Cain, so sometimes God takes those who are dear to our heart, hoping to 
open our eyes and let us start believe in his Grace. 

If you think about it, aids is a punishment because of homosexuality, I am 
not condemning anyone nor am I judging, I am just making a point as to my 
experiences and beliefs. 

Now to bring up the "baseball player hitting a home run" I can assure you, 
with all due respect, God doesn't care about sports, games, or anything 
that keeps our focus off of him. 

I've had a lot of experiences in life that God truely exists, from the time 
I was diagnosed with SIDS, even now when my ex-girlfriend had a baby with 
no ovaries, and my grandfather was told by doctors in 2001 that due to his 
excessive drinking and drug addiction problem in the past that he had 6 
months to live, he is still alive today.

I tell you all these because I have experienced it and I believe it. Thank 
you for taking the time to read this. I do know it was long and I do 
apologize.
comments.author: Ryan LevRon Jr

comments.text:
+Larry L

Well I love you and I think you are just fine even I think you are all

comments.author: Larry L

comments.text:
If you don't believe in a God then why watch a video about someone who 
does? If Love is such a human tendency; why is there so much hate than 
Love? We have our RELIGIOUS freedom as you have yours...for someone who 
doesn't believe in a God, why did you waste your time writing your comment? 
It's very simple; you either believe or you don't...don't scrutinize what 
others believe in, respect it, an move on. GBY
comments.author: Spartan Kratos

comments.text:
I'm glad you tried to be Christian; many wouldn't even try. You also seem 
very reasonable and polite, so thank you for sharing your views in such an 
agreeable fashion. I respect that.
comments.author: Savanna Eley

comments.text:
+Savanna Eley
That's a very fair question Savanna; as an atheist, why would I care so 
much about other human beings? The truth is, I can't provide an intelligent 
or quantifiable answer to that but ever since I was a child I have had a 
tremendous compassion for humanity.

Respectfully, I arrived at this video because it appeared on my Facebook 
page. I trust you would agree that I have as much right to respond to it as 
my friend had to post it or that Jon Jorgenson had to put it on YouTube in 
the first place. If somebody has a right to express their faith, don't I 
have an equal right to refute it?

FWIW, I have no designs in attempting to "convert" christians to atheism 
and even if I did, I don't have that kind of power. I reply to these videos 
so that those who are "on the fence" can hear both sides of the story. I 
tried to be christian for several years for fear of admitting who I really 
am and what I truly accept; there is nothing worse than lying to ones self. 
I speak out now so that others in a similar situation can avoid making the 
same mistake I made and also to help people see that atheists are not 
immoral, devil-worshiping heathens. Many of us are kind, loving people that 
have simply never bought into what religion sells.
comments.author: Larry L

comments.text:
+Larry L if we all die and go nowhere, then why do you care what people do 
or think in their life? Just let people have faith in what they believe, 
and leave them to it. Everyone has faith in something, whether it is proven 
right or wrong, and they should be able to express opinions and express 
their faith in their God freely without people commenting on it. Leave 
people alone. We all have faith in something.
comments.author: Savanna Eley

comments.text:
+DireldaKitsune
Thank you for replying Direlda, I truly appreciate your comments. First 
off, wouldn't crediting a friend for my actions be like lying? All I'm 
really hoping to convey is that love can be shared with or without a deity; 
if I'm viewed a braggart for sharing my own experience, so be it. While I 
wouldn't like it, I prefer that to being dishonest.

Second, I don't think I could agree more; there are things in life that are 
outside of our control - bad things happen to good people but how we 
process those events is within our control. There are countless examples of 
people who had difficult beginnings and went on to achieve greatness - 
Nelson Mandela comes to mind. The reality is, we can only control what we 
can control and humbly accept that which we can't.

Third, regardless of which factors are at play with a baseball player, they 
are in play whether the player strikes out or hits a homer. So why give god 
credit when things go well while never holding him/her/it accountable when 
they go poorly? For that matter, why involve a god at all?

Finally, when reward and punishment are part of the equation, it's not 
possible to know if an action is one of pure love or one of self-interest. 
Nonetheless, assuming that you're correct and that some religious people do 
act out of pure love; the point remains the same - god is not required; 
love is simply love.

PS. We also don't choose to carry the burden of Adam and Eve's sins and yet 
here we are - at least according to christianity.
comments.author: Larry L

comments.text:
+Larry L
 No one is responsible for everything that happens in their life. A person 
can't make a tornado not hit their house.  Getting hired or accepted into a 
graduate program has just as much to do with the people making the decision 
and the pool of applicants as it does with the person applying. A foster 
kid isn't able to get only the good foster parents and avoid the abusive or 
neglectful foster parents, nor is the foster kid able to prevent themselves 
from being moved from family to family.  A person doesn't chose the 
socioeconomic status, ethnic group, country, and family they are born into. 
Regardless of what someone believes about God's existence or non-existence, 
there are things outside of people's control that affect their lives in 
both negative and positive ways.

For instance, to use your baseball example, if it were true that it was 
just hard work, dedication, and practice that led to a batter hitting a 
homer, then one would expect that batters would get to a point where every 
ball they hit would be a homer.  But that is not the case.  There are other 
variables, such as the pitcher, the speed and type of ball thrown, and the 
weather (especially wind) to name a few, that affect whether or not a ball 
becomes a homer.  And even the most hard working, dedicated batter with 
years and years of practice can strike out.  Now whether someone chooses to 
reduce these occurrences to physical causes, or call it luck, or see it as 
God working things out is up to them.  But the reality remains that there 
is something more than just a person's own efforts at work.

Granted, the view that people are responsible for everything, good or bad, 
that happens in their life can be rather inspirational and motivate people 
to stop commenting on YouTube, get up off their bums, and make positive 
changes in their life and/or the world.  However, this view has a dark 
side, which is why I've taken the time to reply.  Because if people are 
responsible for everything that happens in their life, then every bad thing 
that happens to them is their own fault for not being good enough, smart 
enough, and so on.  So in this view, it is the foster kid's fault that they 
were placed in an abusive family and that if they just tried harder they 
wouldn't be abused.  And that is ABSOLUTELY wrong. These "slings and arrows 
of outrageous fortune" are not their fault.

Now that the mischief is done, it's time for this fox to run.
Blessings and peace!
~Direlda

Oh, and if you didn't mean to brag, then why didn't you tell us that it was 
a friend of yours who did all those good things? Most of us on YouTube 
wouldn't know better.  It's absolutely wonderful that you do such work and 
you should keep at it.  Seriously, the world needs more people who do good 
out of love. But if you don't want to come across as bragging, tacking on 
"I don't mean to brag" at the beginning or end isn't the way to do it. All 
that does is come across as another way of trying to look good.  Better to 
pretend that it's somebody else who has done your good if you want to be 
humble.  Also, not everyone who believes in God does good as a way of 
earning points for heaven or avoiding hell--some of them are like you in 
that they do it out of love.
comments.author: DireldaKitsune

comments.text:
God put a calling in my heart ever since I met God so he does use us to 
answer others' prayers
comments.author: gohar harutyunyan

comments.text:
+Jas Lopez
Jas, as you have surmised, I am an atheist. I wrote and published a book to 
help people lose weight and live healthier lives and I give that book away 
to people at significant expense to myself. I also give money to homeless 
people, volunteer at shelters and provide free counseling to those who wish 
to change their lives. I don't say these things to brag, only to illustrate 
that people can be good without a deity in their lives. Taken further, I do 
these things purely out of love for others and not to win points towards a 
heaven or to avoid being tossed into hell. And to be clear, nothing or 
nobody influenced me that there is no god. You were not born a christian - 
that was something YOU had to be influenced into by somebody or a life 
experience.

I really don't wish to sound like one of those angry anti-god atheists that 
lives to insult christians; in fact, the opposite is true. I would just 
like christians to accept reality; that THEY are the ones responsible for 
everything in their lives be it good or bad. For example, baseball players 
that look up to the sky when they hit a home run - IT WAS NOT GOD; it was 
years of hard work, dedication and practice that helped them hit the homer. 
Why don't those same players look up at the sky and ask "Why have you 
failed me?" when they strike out? Imagine how a starving child might feel 
when that player thanks god for helping him hit his home run.

Finally, there is no such thing as a "god follower". People follow rules of 
the bible (written by humans) or as laid out by a human 
priest/minister/rabbi (also humans). Just because a human being said that 
the bible was inspired by god doesn't make it true any more than if the 
author who wrote "Fifty Shades of Gray" were to make the claim.

I'm sorry, this got longer than intended.
comments.author: Larry L

comments.text:
Funny I agree with you in all except the we don't need God part. 
Unfortunately People who claim they are Christians have done a bad job 
representing God and what he is all about. God made human beings for the 
reason you stated  we provide love for each other, joy, support and 
compassion. Unfortunately some humans can be evil, self centered and 
selfish. Anyone who uses the excuse of God did not call on me is not being 
a true God follower but that doesn't mean we don't need God. If anything it 
proves even more how much we need indeed need him. God is Love we love 
others because he loved us first. God new you and loved you before you were 
even born.
You said "Turning away from somebody in need is deplorable whether "god" 
calls on you or not." SO TRUE!!!!!!!!!!! but that goes back to showing how 
people can being selfish and inconsiderate. But not everyone is like that.
Prayer is a powerful tool. Praying is a solemn request for help or 
expression of thanks addressed to God. Some people think I pray and sit 
back and watch something happen. Although that is possible it's not always 
the case. You are right get up off your butt and do something. God never 
said be lazy and expect me to hand everything to you. No we talk to God 
through prayer the same way we do with someone we trust. But actions on our 
part also have to be taken. I am sorry someone or a life experience has 
influenced you to believe there is no God. But I believe there is and my 
life is proof of that. God Bless.
comments.author: Jas Lopez

comments.text:
+nikomi mukthuy
I'm afraid that you're missing the point; I'm actually not claiming that 
god does not exist; the fact is, I have no way of proving it either way. As 
such, I don't take any exception to a god. However, religion does exist and 
it's that which I (and most other atheists) take exception to.

If a god DOES exist, I suspect that he/she/it would not be pleased with the 
representation proposed by organized religions. If somebody wishes to 
believe in a god, fine; but if that same person uses said belief to 
manipulate the beliefs and actions of another, then we need to seriously 
review what the belief really is.
comments.author: Larry L

comments.text:
+jmanc3 See that's where you are mistaken love... I am not trying to prove 
anything to anyone. It was just a question to think about nothing more 
nothing less. And as for me not being mad at God... It is a choice I made I 
believe that even through that dark moment God was there. It could have 
been a lot worse than what it was.. the man was looking for sexual 
fulfillment and after I cried out to God that man actually walked out 
of the room.... Look I don't push my faith on anyone I only state my 
opinion. An opinion which is based on my life experience. you can take it 
or leave it. No one is forcing you to  believe what I believe. But 
here is something for you to think about... You along with many people say 
that God ain't real because you don't see how a good God can exist with all 
this evil in the world. If God is real then He should stop all this evil, 
because He's all-powerful right? But what is evil? It's anything that's 
against God. It's anything morally bad or wrong. It's murder, rape, 
stealing, lying, cheating. But if we want God to stop evil, do we want Him 
to stop it all or just a little bit of it? Do we want him to stop everyone 
but us? Or what about everyone except our love ones? If He stops us from 
doing evil things, what about lying, or what about our evil thoughts? I 
mean, where do you stop, the murder level, the lying level, or the thinking 
level? If we want Him to stop evil, we gotta be consistent, we can't just 
pick and choose. That means you and I and our loved ones would be 
eliminated right? Because we think evil stuff, we lie, we cheat, we 
steal. If that's true, we should be eliminated! But thanks to God's 
loving mercy he sent his only son to die for our sins so that we wouldn't 
have to. So he can give us chances amongst chances to repent and turn from 
our evil ways. I am not saying we have to be perfect because the truth is 
we will never be perfect. But that is why God has mercy on human kind. God 
sees the best in us and allows you the opportunity to make a change.  Be 
blessed... JAS
comments.author: Jas Lopez

Rocka Rolla I respect your comment and I am sorry you feel that way but 
What if you are wrong? What if there is that slight chance that there is a 
God and you denied him? I suggest that before you set your mind on if there 
is or isn't a God you should research it first. I was molested at 10 by a 
family member scared me for years and I could have blamed God for it but I 
didn't. What I can say is that God healed me and that part of my past 
doesn't hurt me anymore in fact I use that as one of my testimonies for 
those who have been in the same shoes. God can make something good out of 
something bad and he has revealed to me that he is real. And I pray that 
you may open your pretty little eyes and see that he is in fact real and 
the better then anything the world can offer.

captions.text:
So yesterday I was reading my Bible, and I
came to this verse in Psalm that really got

me thinking, and it really just kind of stuck
to my heart. It's in Psalm 102 and it's verse

17. It says, He will respond, He, God, will
respond to the prayer of the destitute. And

this verse, it got me thinking about a lot
of the things that have been happening around

our world. It got me thinking about typhoons
in the Philippines, and it got me thinking

about tornados in central Illinois, and it
got me thinking about people who, in a matter

of hours, lost everything, lost their homes,
some lost their families, lost their jobs,

lost their towns, lost their possessions,
and they find themselves completely destitute.

And even beyond that, it got me thinking about
the millions of people around the world for

whom their poverty is not a result of natural
disasters, but it's a reality that they're

forced to live with each and every day. Every
day they try and find food. Every day they

try and find clean drinking water. They are
homeless all the time. And even beyond that,

it got me thinking about those who are spiritually
destitute, those who, in the last year, have

lost a family member, or who have lost their
job, or have gone through a divorce, or sickness

has completely overtaken their family, and
they're just left confused or angry or wondering

where they're supposed to go next. And I can't
help but think about the prayers of those

who are physically or spiritually destitute
and how their prayers must outnumber my own

by thousands, because we all know that it's
only when we have nothing that we finally

begin to realize how much God is truly everything.
And in light of all of those prayers that

are prayed by those who are destitute, I think
this verse provides a lot of much needed hope

because the verse says He, God, will respond
to those prayers. See, God doesn't just hear

those prayers. He responds. He moves. He acts.
He answers those prayers. And now I know that

there's more than one person out there who
is saying, "No no no, Jon, you don't understand,

I've been praying. I've been praying that
my son would finally come home. I've been

praying that someone would come and help us
rebuild our house. I've been praying and praying

that I would get a job. I've been praying
and praying and praying, and God is not responding."

See, I believe that God has many, many ways
for how He likes to respond to prayer, but

I think the most important, and the most necessary,
and also the most underutilized is me and

you, the Church, His followers, men and women
who are fully consecrated to performing His

purposes here on earth. I believe that we
are God's Plan A for answering and responding

to the prayers of the destitute. I like to
think of prayer in terms of a triangle where

a request is given up to God, who in turn
turns it into a calling which is given to

someone as inspiration, someone who has the
ability to answer the request. So perhaps

it's not that God isn't responding to those
prayers; perhaps it's that we are not responding

to God's call to answer them. See, we as Christians
love to get on our knees and ask God for the

desires of our hearts, and don't get me wrong,
I believe that God loves that. He loves when

we tlak to Him, and He loves when we ask Him
for things, especially when those things align

with His will. But if we're all just sitting
around asking God to answer our prayers, it's

like we're missing two halves of a triangle.
You see, the question is not, "Who's going

to answer my prayer?" The question is, "Whose
prayer is God going to use me to answer?"

Let me say that again 'cause that's really
good. The question is not, "Who's going to

answer my prayer?" The question is, "Whose
prayer is God going to use me to answer?"

The calling that's on your heart, the calling
that God has placed on your heart, that's

God calling you to be the light in someone
else's darkness, to be the hope in someone's

hopelessness, to be the comfort in their despair,
to be the spark in their revolution, to be

the joy in their sadness. That's God calling
you to be the answer to somebody's prayers.

No, the question, the question is not, "Will
God respond to the call of the destitute?"
No, the question is, "Will you?"

title: Does God Respond To Prayer? - Jon Jorgenson
